content: Unexpected meeting of husband and wife.
child:
Unknown wife supernaturally conceals herself until the favorable moment to come
forward. Italian: Crane 340; Greek: Garnett II 18; Hindu: Rouse FL V 85.
Husband and wife become separated in shipwreck.

Wife unexpectedly meets husband on street. They are
reunited. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Slandered queen chances to be in Rome at the same time as
her estranged husband.

Reconciled by the
Pope. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Calumniated wife is forced to flee.

(Cf. †K2210.) Reunited
by chance after many years at Emperor‘s court.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Husband and wife reunited after long separation and tedious
quest.
Maiden found in magic garden; prince’s wife in former life.

content: Abandoned children accidentally discovered by villainess.

Accidental meeting of seeker of exiled prince with prince
at meal.

Messenger in pilgrim garb invites
unknown prince to eat with him. Recognition. *Boje 85.

Person accidentally met unexpectedly knows the other‘s
name.
Hero captured by man he has formerly rescued: rewarded.
Unwitting combat between sons of friends.

Recognition and
reconciliation. (Cf. †N731.2.) Greek: Fox 128 (Glaukos and Diomedes).
Adventures from pursuing objects carried off by bird.
Adventures from pursuing object carried off by river.

Accidental meeting with the son of the only person who can
overcome curse on hero.
Unexpected meeting of father and son.
child: Unknown son returns to father‘s court.
King unknowingly adopts his own lost son.

Neither knows who the other is. (Sohrab and Rustem.) **Potter
Sohrab and Rustem; Deutschbein I 232ff.; Potter FL XV 216ff.; Rank Inzest-Motif
164ff.; Hibbard 227 n. 5; *Köhler-Bolte II 256ff.; L. Wolff Hessische Blätter
f. Volksk. XXXIX 54--63. -- Irish: *Cross, MacCulloch Celtic 145, 169
(Cuchulainn, Fionn), Thurneysen 403ff.; English: Wells 135 (Sir Degare);
Icelandic: *Boberg; Greek: Fox 140 (Telegonos and Odysseus); Arabian: Burton
Nights VII 89 n.; Persian Carnoy 332; Chinese: Werner Myths 315--319, Coyajee JPASB XXIV 179; Philippine: Dixon 235; Hawaii:
Beckwith Myth 508.
Hero fights with friend of father and then reveals himself.
English: Wells 17 (Reinbrun, Gy son of Warwike).

Undesired combat between sworn (blood) brothers (foster
brothers).
Father unexpectedly meets abandoned son and reinstates him.

At execution block condemned man discovered to be king‘s
unknown son.

(Cf. †N731.2.2.) Dickson
100, 109, 153; Icelandic: Boberg; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G. 13/317).
Brother unwittingly kills half brother in fight.

Elder brothers unwittingly come to maltreated youngest in great need. Eventual
recognition. India: Thompson-Balys.

Two returning brothers unwittingly purchase bird, which is
transformed youngest brother, as present intended for him.

Brothers accidentally reunited when wedding of one to a
king’s daughter is celebrated and neighboring rulers are invited.

content: Accidental meeting of father and daughter.
child:
Father unwittingly buys daughter who has been sold into
slavery.
Deserted daughter’s good fortune discovered by accident.

Daughter‘s good fortune accidentally discovered by father
who has become a beggar.

Parents accidentally meet daughter who has survived their
attempts to drown her.

content: Accidental meeting of mother and son.

Irish myth: *Cross; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys;
Chinese: Graham.
child: Begging ascetics beg alms of their own mother.

content: Accidental meeting of brother and sister.
child:
Slaves ordered married discover they are brother and
sister.
Saint prays with woman; learns she is his sister.

content: Accidental meeting of mother and daughter.
Accidental meeting of nephew and uncle.

Hero takes refuge unwittingly at his uncle’s court.
*Dickson 143 n. 143; Icelandic: *Boberg.
child: Uncle and nephew unwittingly about to kill one another.

content: Race with fairies leads to adventures.

Adventures from pursuing enchanted animal (hind, boar,
bird).

(Guiding Beast.) Types 710 (Grimm
No. 3), 425; *Tegethoff 14; **Pschmadt Die Sage von der verfolgten Hinde
(Greifswald, 1911); Dickson 53f.; Clouston Tales I 215; *Fb “hjort” I 625a;

25--26, Sveinsson FFC LXXXIII xxxiii, *Boberg; Italian: Basile Pentamerone I
No. 9, *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; New Britain: Dixon 140.
child: Runaway ox leads pursuer to burial place of Adam and Eve.

content:
Dropped ball (basket) leads to adventures when recovery is
attempted.
child:
Adventures encountered in running after cotton being blown
away by wind.
Bucket dropped into well leads to adventures.
Flax dropped into well leads to adventures.
Spindle dropped into well leads to adventures.

content:
Light seen from tree lodging place at night leads to
adventures.

*Type 130, 327; *Aarne FFC XI 111; BP I 115ff.; Missouri French:
Carrière; Japanese: Ikeda.
child: Climbing tree to look around leads to adventures.
Adventures from trying to strangle oneself in tree.
Adventures from having slept beneath tree.

content: King (prince) lost on hunt has adventures.
child: King on hunt is taken prisoner.
Girls going in the wood for nuts have adventures.

Feast as occasion for the beginning of adventures or the
arrival of questers.

content: Adventure from following animal to cave (lower world).

*Type 301; Irish myth: *Cross; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 66
No. 508 A*, Espinosa Jr. No. 67; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 163; N. A.
Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 74.
child: Adventure from following ogre to cave.

content: Parting at crossroads to go on adventures.

*Type 303; *Ranke FFC
CXIV (motif †B2); India: Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Graham.
Lovers first see each other on shores of lake.
M. Bloomfield in Penzer VII xxiii; India: Thompson-Balys.
child: Hero finds maiden at fountain (well, river).

content: King marries girl who finds lost object of his.
child:
Princess catches raja‘s golden bird; he trails it to her
palace.
King marries girl who finds his lost ring.

content: Taking refuge in a grave leads to adventure.
King (prince) accidentally finds maiden and marries her.

*Types 403, 451, 705, 709; *BP I 99ff., 295ff.; Irish
myth: *Cross; Icelandic: Boberg; Spanish: Espinosa II Nos. 99--103, Espinosa
Jr. Nos. 80, 115; Italian: Basile Pentamerone I No. 8; India: *Thompson-Balys.
child: King (prince) finds maiden in woods (tree) and marries her.

*Types 550, 551, 706; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. No. 106;
India: Thompson-Balys.
Prince sees maiden at church and is enamored.

*Types 510AB; Missouri
French: Carrière; Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 111f., Espinosa Jr. No. 119.

Prince (king) finds girl floating on water in basket:
marries her.

Hertel Zs. f. Vksk. XIX
83ff.; Penzer II 5; Italian: Basile Pentamerone III No. 2; India:
Thompson-Balys.
Prince sees heroine at ball and is enamored.

content:
Prince first sees heroine as she comes forth from her
hiding-box.

She has concealed herself
until the favorable moment. *Cox 489; India: Thompson-Balys.
child:
Princess concealed in trunk and sent to beggar, who marries
her.

content: Lover sees beloved first while she is bathing.
N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 88.

child:
Man hunting honey encounters lost maiden, returns her to
her parents.

content:
Anchor catching in oratory of submarine monastery leads to
adventures.

Köhler-Bolte I 189;
*Schoepperle Tristan and Isolt II 370ff.; Irish myth: *Cross.

Mother‘s parting gift to adventuring son: the two loaves of
bread.

One for hunger, one for overeating.
India: Thompson-Balys.

Broken vessel (calabash, etc.) to be mended leads to
adventure.

Africa (Guinea Coast): Trautmann La Litterature à la Côte des Esclaves (Paris,
1927), West Africa: Travélé Proverbes et contes Bambara (Paris, 1923) 205ff.,
No. 66, Frobenius Atlantis VIII 274ff. No. 120.

Incidents when wife takes food to husband in field or
forest.

Hunter accidentally discovers beautiful girl being secretly
reared in a cave.
Girl sees man as he lies sleeping by wayside.
Runaway horse carries bride to her lover.

Bridegroom unwittingly
hires a horse belonging to his rival for his bride to ride to the wedding. A
storm arises and the horse carries her to his master. *Bédier Fabliaux 119,
473.

child:
Man, thinking it an enemy, flees as sweetheart comes after
him in pursuit.
Princess accidentally elopes with wrong man.
Man falls into jar of honey and is drowned.
Chases a mouse. Greek: Frazer Apollodorus I 310 n. 2.

Death from greed. Wienert FFC LVI 61 (ET 242), 146 (ST 512); Halm Aesop No.
293.
Foxes crowd into house and are suffocated.
Groom killed by lightning on wedding night.

Uxorious king is burned to death while taking an alcohol
bath.
Man forgets to wear magic gown and is killed.
Army drowned by unnoticed incoming tide.
Accidental death from fall on own weapon (shield).

Accidental death of father from fall into the fire when
taking down weapons for his son.

Girl abducted by fairy left on shore, where she is
accidentally drowned.

Youth gazing at own image reflected in water falls and
drowns.

Girl lets down her sari for hero to climb up by but, when
he is halfway up, sari breaks and he is killed.

Prefect, cursed by bishop, dies of fish-bone stuck in his
throat.
Accidental death by striking head against lintel of door.

Wife throwing husband’s corpse into river (according to
custom) is caught by corpse‘s arm and drowned.

Thief crushed to death by fallen fragments of wall he has
bored.
King mortally wounded on killed enemy‘s tooth.

Bottle wherein jinn is imprisoned inadvertently opened and
jinn escapes to kill his captor.

content: Death as result of mistaken identity: wrong person killed.
child: Saint changes places with charioteer; latter is killed.
Son killed because mistaken for someone else.
Father orders unrecognized son thrown into sea.

content: Unexpected death at hands of an animal.
child: Bird hunter killed by adder just as he is shooting bird.

Wienert FFC LVI 65 (ET 295), 207 (ST 197); Halm Aesop No.
171; India: Thompson-Balys.
Blood bath causes woman to be carried off by bird.

A pregnant woman demands a bath of blood: husband
substitutes a bath of red dye. A Garuda bird attracted by the dye carries her
off. Penzer I 97; Dunlop-Liebrecht 135.

Sick queen lying under red satin carried off by bird who
thinks it is red meat.

Ants gnaw a bowstring, so that the bow rebounds and cuts off head of man who is
leaning on it. *Bloomfield in Penzer VII xx ff.
Accidental death from flying splinter of bone.

Bone being gnawed by animal lets splinter fly and kills
young animals. Africa (Larusa): Fokken “Erzählungen und Märchen der Larusa”
ZsKS VII 82ff. No. 1, (Wachaga): Gutmann 87ff. No. 44, (Masai): Fuchs Sagen,
Mythen und Sitten der Masai (Jena, 1910) 50ff., (Uganda): Rowling The Tales of
Sir Apolo: Uganda Folklore and Proverbs (London, n.d.) 47ff., (Congo): Stanley
My Dark Companions and their Strange Stories (New York, 1906) 161ff., Casati
Ten Years in Equatoria and the Return with Emin Pasha (New York, 1891) II 45f.
Attacking animal is killed by another in ambush.

Tortoise lands on elephant‘s back so that elephant’s back
is broken.

content: Accidental fatal ending of game or joke.
child:
*Type 2401; *BP I 202;
Wesselski Archiv Orientální II 431; England, U.S.: Baughman.
Hanging in game or jest accidentally proves fatal.

Wesselski Theorie 18; Fb “hænge” I
731b; Danish: Christensen DF XLVII 200 No. 36; Icelandic: Boberg; Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. 3309, Legends Nos. 605 609; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 122 Nos.
40, 41.
Practical joker asks doctor to castrate him.

Doctor insists on the operation. Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.

Hero, while measuring wild boar, accidentally wounded
mortally by bristle.
Axe thrown at one animal misses but kills another.

content:
Man dodging blow in dream hits his head against wall and
kills himself. Alphabet No. 285.
Things accidentally fall and kill person.
child: Dagger in wall above bed falls and kills girl.

Has been placed there by her lover. Indonesia: De Vries’s
list No. 219.
Knife accidentally strikes girl‘s throat and kills her.

Prince’s arrow accidentally grazes breast of merchant‘s
wife.
Bride lets dagger fall and kill husband.

Bread accidentally dropped from tree on bear’s nose kills
bear.

Man hidden in tree so frightened of lioness he drops his
sword and kills her.

content: Aiming at fly has fatal results.
child: Person killed by hitting fly on his face.

Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys;
Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesia: De Vries‘s list No. 285. Cf. Type 1586.
To give child a slap to stop its crying, numskull kills it.
Man accidentally killed by bear trying to chase away flies.
Man accidentally fed bread which his father has poisoned.

The wicked man puts poison in the bread he gives a beggar.
The beggar gives his loaf to the son. Type 837; *De Vries Tijdschrift voor
Nederlandsche Taal- en Letterkunde XLVII 63ff.; India: *Thompson-Balys.

Poisoned bath prepared for another accidentally used by
hero.
Horse accidentally poisoned instead of master.

An attempt is made to give the hero a poisoned cup. He is
on horseback and spurs his horse away to avoid the cup. The poison is spilled
and enters the horse‘s ear and kills him. *Type 851; *BP I 189; Spanish:
Espinosa Jr. No. 131.
Elephant on rampage accidentally poisoned instead of man.
Man claims having killed elephant. India: Thompson-Balys.

Serpent carried by bird lets poison drop into milk and
poisons drinkers.
Head of killed snake bites and kills king.
Snake in jug bites would-be thief.

Boy accidentally drinks “poison” intended for his
stepbrother.

Doctor had substituted
sleeping potion for the requested poison. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Youth accidentally takes the poison he intended for his
father.
Mistakes poison for medicine. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Man eats food which is mysteriously poisoned.

S. A. Indian
(Chiriguano): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 177; Jewish: *Neuman; Buddhist myth:
Malalasekera II 511.
Hidden fruit accidentally poisoned by snake.

content:
Robber attempting to steal cow at night seizes thieving
tiger.
child:
Escaping prisoner falls by accident onto tiger‘s back and
is carried away.
Woman errs on to the road-of-the-tiger: carried off.

S. A. Indian
(Chiriguano): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 161.

content:
Lover who is
detained away beyond stipulated time returns to find fiancée married.
child:
Hospitality enforced on hero keeps him overlong from home;
meantime wife abducted.

Mistress expecting lover accidentally exchanges places with
her maidservant.

content: Watchman falls asleep as enemy approaches. Irish myth: Cross.
Man blinded trying to heal girl.

Powders blow into his one good eye. Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.
Delay in bringing pardon allows deserved execution.

Messenger, ignorant of contents of message, stops to view
culprit’s execution. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
child: Sign of prisoner‘s reprieve changed by wind.

A flag to be flown in certain way, but wind catches it
just at the wrong moment so that prisoner is executed. Korean: Zong in-Sob 61
No. 34.

Shipwrecked man lands on deadly enemy’s territory and is
attacked.
Man‘s inordinate laughter brings unfortunate results.
Man discovers he is married to wer-tiger.

content:
Mistake in interpreting prophecy (oracle) brings
misfortune.
Separation of persons caused by looking for water.

*M. Bloomfield in Penzer VII xxiv ff.; India:
*Thompson-Balys.
Father kills self believing that son is dead.

The son forgets to spread white sails, the prearranged
signal of his safety. (Told also of lovers.) *Schoepperle II 437f.; Greek:
Frazer Apollodorus II 137 n. 4.
child: Wrong sign put out leads to boys‘ leaving home.

They are to be informed by a sign if a sister is born.
*Type 451; BP I 70ff.; Italian: Basile Pentamerone IV No. 8.

Father causes death of innocent son, believing him guilty
of adultery with father’s wife.

content:
An impoverished suitor has only a falcon to catch birds
with. His lady‘s sick son wants the falcon and she goes to ask for it. The suitor
serves dinner for her--his falcon. When she makes her request it is too late.
*Bédier Fabliaux 153f.; Boccaccio Decameron V No. 9 (*Lee 170); Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.
Pigeon hastily kills his mate for stealing wheat.

It has merely dried out
and no longer fills the nest. When the dampness later swells the wheat, he sees
his mistake and kills himself in remorse. Chauvin II 104 No. 66; Bødker
Exempler 302 No. 69; Spanish Exempla: Keller; India: Thompson-Balys.

Icelandic: *Boberg. Cf. death of Polonius in Shakespeare’s
“Hamlet”.
child:
Eavesdropping man in disguise as devil killed unwittingly
by daughter‘s lover.

Eavesdropping wife hidden in bushes killed unwittingly by
husband.

content:
*Type 931; *Krappe Balor
13 n. 45; Greek: *Grote I 206; India: Thompson-Balys. See all references to
†M343 (Parricide prophecy).

child: Man unwittingly causes death of daughter.

content: Innocent man accidentally suspected of crime.
child: Clerk who enters tavern arrested with others for murder.

Scala Celi 59a No. 326; Chauvin IX 19; Spanish Exempla:
Keller; Icelandic: Boberg.

Saint who entered house of ill fame to reform inmates
accused of going with evil intent.

Boy is hanged for cattle theft; the strayed cattle are
discovered later.

Man having purchased stolen ornament unwittingly presents
it to owner as gift; is thrown into jail as thief.

Poor man presented rich robe by emperor is locked up as a
thief.

Greedy disciple decides to remain in city despite learned
teacher’s warning and is condemned to take the place of a thief.
Suicide in remorse over hasty condemnation.

King hastily has 7,000 people put to death for stoning his
judges to death.

Woman wrongly condemned for drunkenness when seen to take
one drink.

content:
Misunderstood message causes messenger to be killed
(accused).

Hasty condemnation of man who accidentally becomes
suspected of crime.
child:
Faithful servant guarding master’s wife from danger falsely
condemned for betraying his master.

68.

Faithful son guarding his father from monster falsely
accused by stepmother.
Stumbling over bloody corpse brings accusation of murder.
Man gets blood on himself. *Chauvin V 136 No. 64.
Jealous and overhasty man kills his rescuing twin brother.

*Type 303; Italian: Basile Pentamerone I No. 7; India:
Thompson-Balys.
False accusation overheard causes hasty killing.

Angry brother kills husband, thinking latter had killed
wife (sister) and baby.

She is seen biting off finger of corpse to get its ring.
India: *Thompson-Balys.

content: Lover kills self believing his mistress dead.

She has been frightened
away by a lion. (Pyramus and Thisbe.) Köhler-Bolte I 4; Irish myth: *Cross;

child: Mistress kills self, believing her lover dead.

Irish myth: *Cross; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India:
*Thompson-Balys.
Woman feigns death to meet exiled lover.

It leads to his death. Lover hears of her supposed death,
returns and submits to execution. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Lover commits suicide on finding beloved dead.

content: Separation of twins through being carried off by beast.
Daughter unwittingly turns her own parents out of doors.

child: Boy unwittingly commits incest with his mother.

See all references to
†M344. Heptameron No. 30; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 117 No. 983; Italian Novella:
*Rotunda; Minehassa (Celebes): Dixon 158.
Man unwittingly falls in love with his own mother.

Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Greek: Fox 198
(Myrrha); Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G. 13/116).
Father unwittingly falls in love with daughter.
Brother and sister unwittingly in love with each other.
Boy says, “Whoever eats this mushroom is my wife.”
His own sister eats it and he runs away. India: *Thompson-Balys.

content:
Suspicions aroused when villain leaves his handkerchief in
her room. (Othello.) Italian Novella: Rotunda.

child: Warriors erroneously slay allies in night battle.
Father kills his son in battle rage.

King, seeing eldest son leaving room, decides that he is a
rakshasa.

content: Child follows bird and loses its mother.
Unwitting murder because of insane illusion.
child: Man kills son thinking that he is cutting a branch.
Women, driven mad, devour their infants’ flesh.
Mother kills son thinking him a wild beast.

content: Drop of honey causes chain of accidents.

Hunter drops honey in a
grocery; weasel eats honey; cat chases weasel; dog chases cat; grocer kills
dog: all the cause of a bloody feud between villages. *Taylor JAFL XLVI 87 No.
2036; BP II 104 n. 2; *Wesselski Hessische Blätter f. Vksk XXXII 21; Chauvin
VIII 41 No. 9; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child: Ant pinching frog causes chain of accidents.

content: Fugitive slave takes wrong road and is caught.
Man falls dead from sudden realization.
child:
Man falls dead when he realizes that he has been riding
over frozen sea.

Man falls dead when he realizes that he has eaten bread
from flour used for abscess plaster.
Chauvin VIII 38 No. 6; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Mother dies of fright when she learns that she was about to
commit incest with her son.

He has
disguised himself to test her chastity. *Krappe Balor 181ff.; Alphabet No. 710
(Secundus).

content:
(Cf. †N383.3.) Italian Novella: Rotunda; Eskimo (Greenland): Rink
228, 439, 452, Rasmussen I 148, II 334, III 61, 97, Holm 26.
child:
Medical students (or student nurses or hospital employees) play trick on one of
their number by suspending a cadaver arm or leg from the light cord in the
person‘s room (sometimes the object is placed in the person’s bed). Some
circumstance keeps them from being on hand to observe the person‘s reaction;
the next day they remember the joke and go to the victim’s room to investigate.
They have to break down the door. They find the victim sitting on the bed--her
hair is snow white--and she is gnawing on the cadaver arm. U.S.: *Baughman.

Death in the graveyard; person‘s clothing is caught; the
person thinks something awful is holding him; he dies of fright.
Wicked stepmother falls into the fire because of fright.
Queen dies from fright because of evil prophecy.

Is frightened to death by the impersonation of demons.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Jester condemned to die on block. Pail of water used
instead of axe. He dies. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Priest frightens boy by tying girl‘s corpse to bell-rope.

In revenge the boy puts the body in the priest’s bed.
Priest flees. Dies from injuries. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Lover frightens mistress as a joke.
She dies from the shock. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Meaning to frighten son, father plays devil or a ghost. Son kills him.
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3443, Legends Nos. 861ff.
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3443A, Legends Nos. 864f.
Woman playing dead to spy on husband killed.

Brothers fall dead at sight of long lost brother whom they
sold into captivity.

content: Separation by being on different banks of stream.
Lover‘s wound breaks while he is in bed with mistress.

He bleeds to death (or is discovered because of the
blood). Schoepperle I 222; von der Hagen I cxxvii; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
child: Lover’s spur catches in sheet when he tries to escape.
Man pinned in bed by weapon caught in quilt.
Quarrel over dog starts the Guelph-Ghibelline feud.

content: Blind men accidentally hurt each other.
(Trying to kill pig, or the like.) Herbert III 71.
Persons fall asleep on rock, which magically shoots upward.
N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 76.

Son returning home after long absence unwittingly killed by
parents.

(Cf. †N338.3.) Type 939*; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 939*; Livonian: Loorits
FFC LXVI No. 9391.

Bird carries off ring which lover has taken from sleeping
mistress’s finger.

He searches for the ring and becomes separated from her. *Penzer
IV 192 n. 1; *von der Hagen I cxxxiii; *Köhler-Bolte II 351; Italian Novella:
Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys.
child:
Bird carries off jeweled veil with which girl had covered
sleeping lover‘s face.

Lover pursues bird
and becomes separated from the girl. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Jewel (garment) carried off by bird from bather.

Clothes have been left on bank of stream. India:
*Thompson-Balys.
Serpent steals jewels: person falsely accused of theft.

Boy‘s servant takes pearl to his wife instead of to
merchant; she throws it away.
Beggar accidentally overlooks money put into his way.

content:
(Sometimes the injuries are mere breeches of tabu.)
*Penzer II 147, VII 92 n. 1.
child:
Person has successive misfortunes while making plans
because he forgets to say, “If God wills.”

(Cf. †G224.1, †J1217.1.) Irish myth:
*Cross; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 848*.

content:
They thus combine and are able to get along. *Type 519;
*Wesselski Arlotto II 255 n. 1; Herbert III 192; Oesterley No. 71; Scala Celi
23b No. 151. -- Irish: MacCulloch Celtic 68, *Cross; Jewish: *Neuman; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 53; N. A. Indian (Navaho):
Alexander N. Am. 174.

West
Africa: Nassau Fetischism in West Africa (London, 1904) No. 2.

child:
*Von Sydow Sigurds strid med Fåvne 19ff.;
Icelandic: Boberg.

English: Wells 8 (King Horn), 11 (Horn Childe and Maiden
Rimnild), 17 (Reinbrun, Gy sone of Warwike), 20 (William of Palerne), 115 (Sir
Eglamour of Artois), 117 (Sir Torrent of Portyngale); Icelandic: Boberg; India:
*Thompson-Balys.
Each of four kings does something to save dying falcon.

King helps princes in exile to avenge their father and take
their homeland back.

S. A. Indian
(Tupenamba): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 168.

Only after hero has performed this service is help
forthcoming. *BP II 392.
Supernatural person disguised as servant as helper.
Saint disguised (as poor man) as helper.

content:
A king chooses as the godfather of his son the first man he meets. The
godfather proves to be supernatural. *Type 652; *BP I 377ff., II 121ff., III
18.

*Types 531, 709; Böklen 84ff.; BP III
18ff.; Malone PMLA XLIII 412; Irish myth: *Cross; Missouri French: Carrière;
India: *Thompson-Balys; Eskimo (Bering Strait): Nelson RBAE XVIII 471; Africa
(Zulu): Callaway 44, (Benga): Nassau 208ff.
child: Giant‘s help secured by feeding him.
Wise giant as foster father of hero.
Giantess as foster mother and helper of hero.
Giantess helps the man she loves.
Monster grateful to hero for being spared becomes helpful.
Ogre magically produces water for caravan.
Chief with three supernatural ogre helpers.

content:
*Types 561, 562; *Aarne MSFO XXV 3--82; *BP
II 535ff., 547ff.; *Fischer-Bolte 215.--Missouri French: Carrière; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 1302; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX
182; Philippine (Tinguian): Cole 67, 140, 142; Samoa: Beckwith Myth 438, 442;
Easter Island: Métraux Ethnology 319, 369, 375; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G. 3/1007, 13/174, 221), Henry Ancient Tahiti (Honolulu, 1928) 520f., Beckwith
Myth 450; S. A. Indian (Mura): Métraux MAFLS XL 36; Africa (Fang): Tessman 194.

Hdwb. d. Märchens I 535b; Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: *Neuman;
India: Thompson-Balys.
child: Man carried through air by angel.

Icelandic: Boberg; Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas I 117,
374.

(Cf. †F441.2.) India: Thompson-Balys;
Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 534.
Gift of gold bracelet from river goddess.

content: Santa Claus as bringer of Christmas gifts.

Greek: Iliad and Odyssey passim; India: *Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth:
Malalasekera I 840, II 504.
child:
Irish
myth: *Cross; Jewish: *Neuman; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 22, 111, 174.
Greek: Grote I 54; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 979.

Gods discuss means of settling dispute among girl’s
suitors.

Venus has girl make her own
choice. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Boy as mysterious housekeeper for buffalo herd.

content:
Types 311, 313; Dickson 52f.; Tobler Epiphanie der Seele 71;
Missouri French: Carrière; India: *Thompson-Balys.
child:
Men find their house mysteriously put in
order. Discover that it is done by a girl (frequently an animal transformed
into a girl). *Type 709; **Böklen Sneewittchenstudien 89ff.; MacCulloch
Childhood 261; *BP I 450ff.; Hatt Asiatic Influences 96--102. -- Breton:
Sébillot Incidents s.v. “menage”; Missouri French:
Carrière; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. Nos. 71--74, 81, Espinosa II No. 114, Boggs FFC
XC 48 No. 327D*; Italian: Basile Pentamerone IV No. 6; India: *Thompson-Balys;
Chinese: Graham; Korean: Zong in-Sob 30; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 152, Dixon 218; New Britain, Philippine,
Melanesia: Dixon 110 n. 25, 224 nn. 27, 28; Philippine (Tinguian): Cole 34;
Eskimo (Kodiak): Golder JAFL XVI 88, (West Hudson Bay): Boas BAM XV 223; N.A.
Indian: *Thompson Tales 335 n. 207; S. A. Indian: *Jijena Sanchez 23,
(Surinam): Alexander Lat. Am. 274; Africa (Ekoi): Talbot 134, 136, (Basuto):
Jacottet 110 No. 16, (Kaffir): Theal 74, (Congo): Weeks 215 No. 11, (Zulu):
Callaway 124.

content:
(Cf. †N832.) Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 105 No. 860; Chinese: Graham;
Korean: Zong in-Sob 47.
Icelandic: Boberg; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Zulu): Callaway 239.
Moreno Esdras (†N829); Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: Neuman.

Dickson 121 n. 64; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3669, Legends No. 621; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G. 3/1386, 13/203, 317).
Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 54 No. 405A*, Espinosa Jr. No. 215; Chinese: Graham.
Type 516; Rösch FFC LXXVII 96; Icelandic: Boberg.

Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Jewish: Neuman;
India: *Thompson-Balys.
child: Hero ransoms maltreated picture of a saint.

As reward he gets help from the grateful saint.
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 506C*.

A wise man (saint, brahmin) recognizes that a man
unwittingly carries a venomous serpent in his proviant sack and warns him.

*Types 307, 329, 480, 512*; *BP III 365ff., 534ff.; *Chauvin VI
109 No. 273 n. 1; Roberts 150. -- Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carrière;
Spanish: Espinosa II Nos. 75, 99 --103, 138f.; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese:
Graham; Japanese: Ikeda; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G. 13/174); Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 461; N. A. Indian (Seneca):
Curtin-Hewitt RBAE XXXII 88 No. 4; Africa (Kaffir): Theal 83.

*Types 316, 400, 480, 707; *BP II 380ff., 466; *Cosquin Études
563; Hdwb. d. Märchens I s.v. “Alte im Walde”; Roberts 150. -- Irish
myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Finnish: Kalevala rune 7; Breton: Sébillot
Incidents s.v. “vieille”; Missouri French:
Carrière; Italian: Basile Pentamerone V No. 9, Rotunda; Spanish: Espinosa II
Nos. 99--103, 126--132, Espinosa Jr. Nos. 107, 109; India: *Thompson-Balys;
Korean: Zong in-Sob 63, 166; Polynesia (general): Beckwith Myth chapt. 17
passim; Hawaii: ibid. 257--264, 491; Tahiti: ibid. 251; Tonga: Gifford 156;

(Basuto): Jacottet 118 No. 17, 142 No. 20, 204
No. 30, 226 No. 33, (Kaffir): Theal 48ff., 82, 145, (Zanzibar): Bateman 128 No.
7, (Angola): Chatelain 47 No. 1, 57 No. 2, 93 No. 5, (Zulu): Callaway 217.

*Hdwb. d. Märchens I
248b; BP III 206 (Grimm No. 150.)
Old woman by spring as helper.

*Type 480; Roberts 151; Italian: Basile Pentamerone IV No.
7.
N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 69.

content: Helper grateful for being bought from slavery.
Train of troubles from lost horseshoe nail.
Master tries to go on in spite of the loss. *BP III 335ff.
Man not fated to die cannot be killed.

Child borne off by tiger, which is caught by griffin, which
is killed by lioness, which rears child with her whelps.
Money cannot be kept from where it is destined to go.

Miser told that his hoard is to go to poor man. He hides
it in a trunk and throws it into the sea but it drifts to the house of the poor
man who tries in vain to restore it to its owner. *Type 745; *Chauvin II 129
No. 137; *Herbert III 234, 377 No. 61, 447; *Oesterley No. 109, Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. 934B*; Russian: Andrejev No. 834B*; West Indies: Flowers 563.
child: Husband‘s magic gift returns to him.

Wife gives husband’s magic gift (fruit) to lover, who
presents it to a dancing girl, who sells it back to the husband. India:
*Thompson-Balys.

content:
The wealthy merchant becomes a beggar, due to the judge’s
boots he acquired through exchange (theft). Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2447*.
Lost object returns to its owner.
child:
(Polycrates.) *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 635;
*Wesselski Mönchslatein 188 No. 146; *Chauvin V 17 No. 10, 141 No. 68, VI 32
No. 202; Fb “ring” IV 328b; Toldo VIII 40;
Saintyves “L‘Anneau de Polycrate” Revue de l’histoire des religions (1912)
1--32; *Loomis White Magic 121.--Irish: Plummer clxxxiv, *Cross; Norwegian:
Solheim Register 20; Italian Novella: Rotunda; Jewish: *Neuman, *Gaster Exempla
210 No. 118, *bin Gorion Born Judas@2 II 106, 344, III 51, 55, 300; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda; Korean: Zong in-Sob 29; Philippine: Fansler
MAFLS XII 7; Africa (Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 133.

Lost articles found in interior of fish through virtue of
saint.
Brooch lost by saint found in fish.

Unavailing attempt to get rid of slippers; they always
return.
Angel helps to find lost pin.

content:
Man must have drinking horn; stumble reveals one as he
departs on search.
Oxen bear dead usurer to gallows to be buried.

They are allowed to go where they will. Pauli (ed. Bolte)
No. 197.

child: Good fortune resides in an object.
Casket with Good Luck in it given to men by Zeus.
Personification of Good Luck lives in man‘s forehead.
Man’s luck resides in his tooth.

Personification of Good Luck leaves palace since king is
destined to die that night.
Luck can be found in certain place.

content:
Missouri French: Carrière; Spanish: Espinosa Jr Nos. 202--209;
Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys.
child: The sun brings all to light.

The murderer repeats as
he sees the rays of the sun, the last words of the dying man, thus betraying
the crime. *Type 960; *BP II 531; *Hdwb. d. Märchens I 98b, *Zachariae Kleine
Schriften 134; *Basset 1001 Contes II 381.
Murder revealed by unusual names of boys.

The dying man leaves message to name his sons “O God” and
“O king” (or the like). This arouses the king‘s curiosity and brings the murder
to light. BP II 336, 535; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 116 No. 960.

Murdered man calls on cranes, the only
witnesses of the murder, to avenge him. The cranes follow the murderer and
point him out. *BP II 532; *Amalfi Zs. f. Vksk. VI 115ff.; *Zachariae ibid. IX
336; Scala Celi 100b No. 539; Hertz Abhandlungen 334; Köhler-Bolte II 563;
Chauvin II 123, VII 146; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 27. -- England:
Baughman; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. No. 209; Jewish: *Neuman.
Ravens pursue murderer who has killed two children.
Murder discovered through knowledge of bird languages.

Murderer through miracle suspected of theft; murder thus
discovered.

Africa (Bantu): Torrend Specimens of Bantu Folk-lore from
Northern Rhodesia (New York, 1921) 9ff. No. 1, 14ff. No. 2.
Murder discovered on digging foundations of house.

House burns. Diggers discover body. Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.
Ship will sink if murderer is aboard.

Murder will out: murderers quarrel under influence of drink
and reveal crime.
Turning right-handwise in certain place brings luck.
Judas Iscariot spills salt at the Last Supper.
Luck changing after change of name.
Luck changing after change of place.

content: Criminal confesses because he thinks himself accused.
child: Criminal confesses because of misunderstood animal cries.

Criminal confesses because of misunderstanding of a
dialect.

Wife misunderstands husband’s remark and confesses. Cent
Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 32.

Thief imagines that group of people in street are talking
and laughing at him; he confesses.
Criminal in church mistakes words of service as accusation.

Sheep thief confesses when preacher says, “All we like
sheep have gone astray.”

**Böklen Die “unglückezahl” Dreizehn (Leipzig,
1913); Hdwb. d. Abergl. s.v. “Zahlen” B 13; *Fb “tretten”; **Kyriakiodos To
Dysoionon tou Arithmou 13 (Athens, 1953).

Nothing escapes a mouse
as long as she has in her hole a purse of money Chauvin II 94 No. 45; Bødker
Exempler 291 No. 49.

The king is to become lucky when he puts on
the shirt of a lucky man. The only man who says that he is lucky has no shirt.
*Type 844; **Köhler Aufsätze 119ff.; H. C. Andersen‘s “Lykkens Galocher”; Edwin Markham’s “The Shoes of
Fortune.”
Feast for those who have not known sorrow.

Dying Alexander’s letter to his mother orders such a feast. No one comes.
*Köhler-Bolte I 579; Köhler Aufsätze 130.
Unlucky to have man in house while cloth is being dyed.
Wife brings bad luck to the husband’s family.
Spirit of adversity brings bad luck to house.
Passenger brings bad luck to ship.

content: Boast of poor boy made good by fate:

he boasts to elder brothers he will build a palace on a
certain spot; accidentally comes on treasure trove and makes good his boast.
India: Thompson-Balys.

After many misfortunes the man is
apparently safe. The wall falls on him. *Type 947; *BP III 289f.; Bødker
Exempler 277 No. 18; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

child: Bad luck follows man who shoots stork.

Wishing to escape it, the luckless couple build themselves a new home. Scarcely
do they establish themselves in the new home, when bad luck addresses them from
the hearth: “I have already waited for you here three days.” Lithuanian: Balys
Index No. 735B*.
Persecution by a god so that will of deity can be followed.

The poor man in some way banishes his bad luck and becomes
prosperous. Out of envy his rich brother sets it free; it then follows him.
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 735A*; Russian: Andrejev No. 735 I*.

content:
Careful builder outside when storm comes is killed;
careless builder saved.

Spanish Exempla:
Keller; Africa (Angola): Chatelain 247 No. 58.
Disagreeable and disliked youth as favorite of Fortune.

child: Prodigal son favored over faithful son.

content: Unprotected son makes fortune; protected son has bad luck.

(Placidas, Eustacius.) His goods are destroyed, his wife
carried off by a ship captain and his children by animals. *Type 938; Herbert
III 241; *Oesterley No. 110; *Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. XXVIII 154f.; Alphabet No.
311; *Hibbard 3ff.; Boccaccio Decameron II Nos. 6, 8 (Lee 34, 39); *Loomis
White Magic 112; **Gerould PMLA XIX 335ff.; Dickson 100 n. 7.--Irish: *Cross;
O’Suilleabhain 42, Beal XXI 315; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Jewish: *Neuman,
bin Gorion Born Judas@2 I 374; India: *Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth:
Malalasekera II 113, 793; West Indies: Flowers 564.
child: Man captured by pirates is maimed, crippled, blinded.

He is patient through it all. Finally he is elected ruler
by his dead master‘s subjects. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Man who aspires to greater wealth loses all.

When he is about to be rewarded by king the latter dies.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Man who loses fortune marries widow of his rich master.

A luckless man becomes successful in all his undertakings
when he marries a lucky woman and lives by her luck. Lithuanian: Balys Index
No. 737B*.
The luckless son and his envious father.

Seeing a luck-bringing animal at his son’s house, the
wizard father orders it to be destroyed, but the grandchildren eat of its meat
and become fortunate. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 738*.
Bad luck put into a sack.

content: Cast-out princess prospers because of Good Luck.

The husband leaves his wife, who has given birth to
fourteen girls, thinking he is persecuted by bad luck because of failure to
have a son. On the seashore, the girls find precious stones. The wife, now
prosperous, finds her husband among beggars. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1668*.
Snake turns to gold in answer to dream.

Woman tells dream of pot of gold. Robbers overhear but
finding only snake in pot turn it loose on woman’s bed. It turns to gold.
India: Thompson-Balys.
Money lost twice: recovered third time.

Type 935**; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 946*; Spanish:
Boggs FFC XC 114 No. 945A*.

child:
Different kinds of luck attending persons born on the
several days of the week.

content: Fortunes of the rich man and of the poor man.

The Fortune of the rich brother tells the poor brother to
seek his luck under a bush. The poor man goes there and Fortune tells him to
become a merchant. He becomes rich. Type 735; India: Thompson-Balys.

Man who derided another‘s faith in the stars becomes
respected astrologer.

Hero fails to meet the man he seeks, though they are close
to one another.

Fugitive woman burdened with child saved; childless woman
killed.

child: Days of the week on which certain tragic deaths occurred.
National disasters occur always at the same date.
Monday and Wednesday as unlucky days.

content: Escape from one misfortune into worse.
child: Stag escapes from hunters to be eaten by lion.

Wienert FFC LVI *49, 55 (ET 86, 152), 116, 136 (ST 261,
417); Halm Aesop No. 129, 252.

Finally the farmer beats him living and will not spare his
hide when he is dead. Wienert FFC LVI 77 (ET 435), 109 (ST 214, 390); Halm
Aesop No. 329.
Halcyon builds nest on sea-cliff to escape land hazards.

Tempest blows nest away. Wienert FFC LVI *63 (ET 266), 140
(ST 4623; Halm Aesop No. 29.

Fugitive slave takes refuge in mill house, where he must
work harder than ever.

Wienert FFC LVI *83
(ET 499), 116 (ST 260); Halm Aesop No. 121.

Daw fleeing from captivity caught in trees by thread around
foot.

Starves. Wienert FFC LVI 63 (ET
265), 116 (ST 259); Halm Aesop No. 202.

Old man burns self with gunpowder, and then burns himself
worse when he pours hot water over his body.

content:
Girls make wish that they may marry king (prince, etc.).
It so happens. *Type 707; *BP II 380ff., 393; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India:
Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 388.

Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth:
Malalasekera I 87, 420, II 824.
child:
Wish realized that all women should fall in love with man
at sight.

content: Destiny better than work, show, or speculation.

A peasant makes a little
by his work; a nobleman more by his outward show; a merchant still more by
speculation; but a prince most of all by his destiny. Chauvin II 109 No. 72;
Bødker Exempler 305 No. 76; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Luck only with money that is earned honestly.

Luck or intelligence? Dispute as to which is the more
powerful.

Man with intelligence remains
poor (is brought into court). Saved by mere luck. *Type 945; BP III 53f.; Tille
FFC XXXIV 254; Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas@2 IV 47, 128, 276, 281; India:
*Thompson-Balys.
child: Which is more important, learning or wit?
Which is more powerful, wealth or wisdom?

Which is more beautiful, nymph of Luck or of Ill-Luck (Luck
when coming, Ill-Luck when going).

Weaver married by Wealth to a princess to show Wisdom that
he is the more powerful.
Dog tries to catch its fate in its own tail.
Buffalo’s fate in bamboo growing from head.

Ill-omened face of king; harbinger of evil. India:
Thompson-Balys.

content:
Man robbed and penniless entertained by wealthy widow and
enriched.

Boccaccio Decameron II No. 2
(Lee 25); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Loss of eye saves man from execution.

Man to be buried with
king. Gets off because he lacks an eye. *Wesselski Märchen 230; Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 480.
child: Broken leg saves man from fatal fight.

King has ordered that he be killed in a fight. He breaks
his leg and cannot take part. Meantime the king learns of his innocence.
Chauvin II 152 No. 18; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Man chosen for execution because he is fat.

King‘s counselor expelled from a court thereby escapes
accompanying the king, who is killed by robbers.
Only crippled cow not driven away by robbers.
Child born with objects that indicate fate.
Spirit of new-born child in uniform.

God has determined fates of everyone. Type 934*;
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 934C*; Livonian: Loorits FFC LXVI No. 934I.

New-born child with a weapon and a game animal: fated to be
hunter.

Mother shown what would have been the evil fates of her
children if they had not died. BP III 472ff.; Irish: Beal XXI 336,
O’Suilleabhain 120.
Newborn girl fated to be a courtesan.
Seventh daughter predestined to be magician.

(Cf. †Z71.5.) Argentina:
Jijena Sanchez 54, 64; Spain: ibid. 69; Portugal: ibid. 70.

content: Train of troubles from sparrow‘s vengeance.

A man runs over the dog, friend of the sparrow. Through
the sparrow’s vengeance the man loses his horse, his property, and finally his
life. *Type 248; *BP I 515; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 254 No. 34.
child:
Train of troubles for seven brothers for having destroyed
bird‘s nest.
He upon whom feather (wisp) falls to be king‘s fool.

Luck determined by whether a crooked-necked demigod is
looking at one.
King to be victorious as long as he rides muzzled gelding.
Districts named from first person met in each.

content: Person brings bad luck to others.
child:
Girl brings ill luck and death to everyone she comes in
contact with.

content:
Whether man begs all day or for an hour he gets only a
small basket of grain.

Man who is impoverished is given high post by princess in
disguise.
Wrecked man saved on coffer of jewels; becomes rich.

Boccaccio Decameron II No. 4 (Lee 30); Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.

*Cosquin Contes Indiens 126f.; Hdwb. d. Märchens II 63 s.v.
Fatalismus; Icelandic: *Boberg; India: *Thompson-Balys.
child: Inexorable fate: no day without sorrow.

A king, who has made decree against sorrow on a certain
day is blinded by a swallow in his sleep. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 481.
Inexorable fate: death from violating tabus.

Man cannot die: snake will not bite him though it is
provoked by him.

Man fated to become king becomes so despite fact he breaks
his tooth in which his luck resides.

content: Fortune comes to deserving and undeserving.
First objects picked up bring fortune.
Man granted power of winning at cards.

Irish: Beal XXI 329, O‘Suilleabhain 90; Spanish: Boggs FFC
XC 45, 52 Nos. 313, 345, Espinosa II Nos. 122ff., 168--171, Espinosa Jr. Nos.
70--73, 210.
Man finds treasure he refused as gift.

child:
Ship‘s course left to the winds that it might be carried
where fate wills it.

At parting of three roads are equivocal
inscriptions telling what will happen if each is chosen. Brothers each choose a
different road. Köhler-Bolte I 537ff.; India Thompson-Balys.

content:
Refused hospitality, he must sleep outdoors. The house burns down.
*Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 479; Jewish: Neuman.

Leopard tied in bag in water floats to shore and finds a
mate.

Grateful to trickster who has tied
him up. India: *Thompson-Balys.

Luck (fate)
thought of as a goddess. **Patch Fortuna; *Penzer I 106f., 135, II 49, 116, III
24, 74, 298, VI 42, 72, 105 n. 1, 124, 156, 159, VII 70, VIII 87; Frazer
Pausanias III 424; India: *Thompson-Balys.
child: Home of Fortuna in other world.
Home of Fortuna on island (in otherworld).
Fortune has one eye, watches over everybody.
Fortune‘s wheel turned by dead king in mountain.

Fortune with pair of scales in his hands weighs man’s
balance.

Man thanks earth for saving his life; had he fallen into
well he would have blamed Fortune.

Wienert
FFC LVI 81 (ET 470), 125 (ST 341); Halm Aesop No. 316; Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Giant is clerk to God of Destiny and measures out mortals’
spans of existence.

content: Lots cast to determine luck or fate.
child: Lots cast to determine who shall undertake adventure.
Lots cast to determine father of illegitimate child.

content:
Spanish Exempla: Keller; Greek: Aeschylus Agamemnon line
860; Jewish: Neuman. Cf. story of Job.
child:
Messengers announce successive misfortunes to warrior as he
sets out for war.

Tells of death of father,
mother, brother, and sister, but he refuses to turn back. Finnish: Kalevala
rune 36.

content: Wager that falsehood is better than truth.

Left to unjust umpire, so that falsehood wins. *Type 613;
*BP II 468ff.; **Christiansen FFC XXIV 47; Chauvin V 11 No. 8, 13 No. 9, 14 No.
158; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 489; India: *Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian: Thompson
CColl II 395.
Wager: more doctors than men of other professions.

The trickster feigns toothache. Everyone suggests
remedies. He takes down their names as doctors and wins the wager. *Wesselski
Gonnella 110 No. 11; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Wager: fortune made from capital or from working at
vocation.

Test: money given to workman is
stolen or lost; lead for his work given him is lent to fisherman who rewards
him with a fish in which is a diamond. *Chauvin VI 32 No. 202.
Wager: woman can be forced to give alms.

Trickster announces that only those who have deceived
their husbands are exempt. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

The servant is sent to a neighbor‘s where he is made drunk
and is seduced by the neighbor’s wife. He tells the master all. *Type 889; Wesselski Märchen 200;
Wesselski Mönchslatein I No. 1; Fb “lyve” II
491a, “sandhed” III 157b; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Spanish: Espinosa Jr. Nos. 70--73, 210; Missouri French:
Carrière; Jewish: *Neuman.
child: Gambling caused by possession of men by evil demons.

Bankrupt gambler gets supernatural power
and wins back his fortune. N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 354 n. 276, (Zuñi):
Benedict II 342, (Klikitat): Jacobs U Wash II 5.
The miracle of broken die at gambling saves man.
Dice made from bones from graveyard.

content: Supernatural adversary in gambling (witch or giant).
child:
India: Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian (Zuñi)
*Benedict II 338.
Stakes not claimed by winner, who insists on another game.
Own body as stake: to be taken as slave.

Missouri French:
Carrière; India: *Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 882; N. A.
Indian: *Thompson Tales 354 n. 277.

*Fb
“spille” III 487b; Icelandic: *Boberg; India: *Thompson-Balys; Burmese: Scott
Indo-Chinese 323; Hawaii Beckwith Myth 111, 459; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales
354 n. 277; Africa (Fjort): Dennett 71 No. 15.

To be
cut off. Penzer II 232n.

*Type
613; Christiansen FFC XXIV 48ff., 55; India: *Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian
(California): Gayton and Newman 82.

*Fb “spille” III 487b, “konge” II 264b; Icelandic: Boberg;
India: *Thompson-Balys; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 429.
Right of succession to the throne lost in gambling.

*Fb
“spille” III 487b; Irish myth: *Cross; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese:
Eberhard FFC CXX 216 No. 165; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 354 n. 276.
Danish: Grundtvig No. 238; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

content:
The parson plays cards all Saturday night, goes to sleep at church, and calls
out the names of the cards. Type 1839A; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1785E*. Cf.
Type 1839B.

child: Devil makes wager with builder of Cologne Cathedral.
Playing game of chance (or skill) with uncanny being.

content:
Trained rat upsets pieces in gambling game: trained (or
transformed) cat chases it away.

child: Luck in gambling from compact with devil.

Scala Celi 24a No. 154; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 55 No.
408A*, Espinosa Jr. Nos. 70--73.

A
man‘s wife is deceived in order that he may lose in gambling. N. A. Indian
(California): Gayton and Newman 81.

content: Elephant is frightened and flees. India: Thompson-Balys.
Wager: to swallow egg with one gulp.

Tricksters give numskull egg with chick in it. Fool hears
chick peep as he starts to swallow his egg, but he says that the chick peeped
too late. Spanish: Childers.

Wager: whose hunger is it more difficult to appease--that
of man or that of beast? When nuts are strewn before master’s well-fed guests,
they snatch and eat them.

Herdsman wins
wager. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1545*.

First object has proved to be ordinary. King induced to
make large wager that second is ordinary. He loses. India: *Thompson-Balys.
Wager: to begin sermon with illustration from card-playing.
Card-playing parson wins the wager. Type 1839B.
Purchase of box without knowledge of its contents.

Wager to win or lose according to whether jackal howls or
ass brays before game is finished.
Father hides wealth to keep son from gambling it away.

Though the man has
foolishly bargained everything away, she praises him and he wins the wager.
Type 1415; *BP II 199; *Hdwb. d. Märchens I 187 n. 131.

Husbands wager that they will be able to do what wives tell
them to do.

One is told to drown himself:
loses wager. England: Baughman.
Wager on the most obedient wife.

The husband tames his
shrewish wife so that he wins the wager. *Type 901; *Wesselski Märchen 216 No.
24; von der Hagen I lxxxii; *Köhler-Bolte I 137; Shakespeare‘s “The Taming of the Shrew”; N. A. Indian (Zuñi): Boas JAFL XXXV 76.
child: Wager: raja’s daughter will bring servant dinner in field.

Merchant ignorant that she is his wife. India:
*Thompson-Balys.

content:
A man
makes a wager on his wife‘s chastity. In spite of unsuccessful attempts to seduce her and of
false proofs presented, he wins the wager. *Type 882; *Köhler-Bolte I 211f.,
375, 581; **G. Paris Romania XXXII 481ff.; *von der Hagen III lxxxiii;
Boccaccio Decameron II No. 9 (Lee 42); Shakespeare’s “Cymbeline”; *Child V 500 s.v. “wager”.--Irish myth:
Cross; Welsh: MacCulloch Celtic 110; England: Baughman; Italian Novella:
*Rotunda; Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas@2 I 276ff., III 109, 304; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 62, 253ff.

child: Wager on sex of unborn child.

Fathers whose unborn children are affianced wager as to
mastery in the house.
Loser of shooting wager to go naked into thorns for bird.

content: Wager: woman to turn somersault in middle of public square.

It is performed not exactly in the center of the square;
hence she loses. India: Thompson-Balys.
Wager: who can call three tree names first.

The bear names different
varieties of the same tree, so that the fox wins the wager. *Type 7; Dh I 193;
Krohn Bär (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 65ff.; Fb “træ” III 867b; N. A. Indian (San Carlos Apache): cf. Goddard
PaAM XXIV 24.
child: Wager about tree names: learned and common names.

Brahmin gives learned names but servant‘s common names are
confirmed by illiterate peasants. India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Wager: it is an auspicious day.

In spite of all
misfortunes wagerer insists that he is right. (Cf. †N127.) India:
Thompson-Balys.
